results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 135]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows a sports or games day, involving a large group of young people, taking place in a garden outside a brick house. The footage shows a large group of people playing various games in a large garden. Some are playing golf, others are playing ‘tenniquoits’ (also known as ‘tennikoit’) where a rubber ring is thrown over a tennis-like net that separates the players. Some of the participants wear striped blazers, others wear blazers that bear a badge or crest - these may be a form of uniform or ‘club colours’ that distinguish two teams.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:55:00 a race is held, with the female-only contestants running the length of a lawn, and stooping to retrieve balls in the grass, which they put into waiting buckets
00:01:21:00 a man (standing in front of a garden hot-house or conservatory) is reading from a sheet in his hands, and appears to be directing events, as others around him move away
00:01:29:00 another race – again with contestants picking-up balls and putting them in buckets – this time includes male and females
00:01:39:00 we see four players of ‘tenniquoits’ – two each side of the net – with a game in progress as a race finishes behind them in a nearby area of the garden
00:01:48:00 a group of people (three women and three men) stand in front of a house that the garden surrounds, probably watching the golf putting that the camera soon shifts to
00:01:59:00 another ball-gathering race is run
00:02:24:00 in another race, the camera stays on a considerably older man – in a suit – running against children and youths
00:02:46:00 we see close-ups of the faces of some of the young people, as the camera moves among them
00:03:08:00 tennis players shake hands across the net
00:03:10:00 a prize-giving ceremony takes place; contestants approach a young woman and receive a small wrapped box, while others applaud in the background

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 131]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows scenes of Sydney and the Blue Mountains, NSW around 1936. There are some wonderful views of Sydney’s waterways including some houses on the lower cliffs, a few bays and a glimpse of the Harbour Bridge. Whilst in the Mountains we see walkers and horseback riding.

Later in the film there are scenes at an air terminal where one of the early Australian air services, the ‘Australian National Airways (ANA)’ is operating. The ANA was established by Charles Kingsford Smith and Charles Ulm in 1930 (ceasing in 1931).

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 family members looking out over the sea from high cliff tops
00:01:20:00, a woman is perched perilously close to the edge of the cliff whilst looking out over the view with her companions
00:02:03:00 small boats appear in the water below
00:02:17:00 family member wandering along a bush track under gums
00:02:50:00 view of the ‘Three Sisters’ at Katoomba in the Blue Mountains
00:03:14:00 member of the family on horseback
00:03:30:00 lots of handshaking and goodbyes at what we see is an air terminal, precedes an ‘Australian National Airways’ plane taking off. Children and adults wave goodbye from very close by when compared to contemporary terminals.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 130]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gadsden children of 1939 at camp, playing ball games, swimming in a river, dressing up for an impromptu pageant in the bush and playing water polo in the river.

The film then changes dramatically to scenes of the State wide bushfires which devastated many parts of regional Victoria on 13 January 1939 and known as ‘Black Friday’.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:23:00 flames in the bush, onlookers
00:01:49:00 sequence of scenes scanning the aftermath of the fires

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 122]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the family at the New South Wales coastal town of Eden, in 1938.

Opens with shots of small, masted boats in harbour (at Eden, New South Wales). One of the boats – with four men in it – is moving out of harbour under engine power.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 a pier, with vehicular rails running along it and a small two-chimneyed ship moored alongside. A small masted vessel is being prepared for launching
00:00:43:00 close-up of a man striding through the camera’s field of vision, then the camera pans slowly over the sea and coastal landscape
00:01:28:00 a bush-fringed road, with a parked car and a man sitting nearby (with back to camera). The camera lingers on the surrounding bush and hills, with the sea visible in the background. This sequence appears to be shot from a vantage point further inland than the earlier coastal scenes
00:01:57:00 two people are standing at the base of a tall building; the camera pans up the structure to show the ‘battlements’ at its top. This is ‘Boyd’s Tower’, a 23 metre structure built in 1847 by the ex-Scottish entrepreneur Ben Boyd, intended as a lighthouse, but never commissioned.
00:02:20:00 entire tower photographed from a slight distance; the full structure can be seen above the surrounding bush
00:02:37:00 same man who appeared earlier in the footage and a woman wearing riding jodhpurs are standing on a rise overlooking the water as the camera pans past them across the scene of bush and sea
00:03:06:00 same man and woman – accompanied by an older woman – are strolling through a park or garden above the coast, looking away from the camera. A dog is frolicking around them, and a horse is grazing nearby.
00:03:24:0 same man walking along a rise, looking away from the camera at the sea and headlands below him. The camera tracks him as he walks further away from it, looking back over his shoulder occasionally.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 121]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gasdsen family and friends enjoying a skiing holiday at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow

A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow
description_for_label:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gasdsen family and friends enjoying a skiing holiday at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmão Film Collection]
results.material_description:
30 x reels 8mm film
Super 8mm and regular 8mm film collection, anotated list of content provided by donor see documents references window.
results.brief_description:
Kirsty Sword Gusmao AO is and Australian-East Timorese activist who served as the First Lady of East Timor from 2002 until 2007. She was married to Xanana Gusmao, Prime Minister and former President of Timor-Leste, now residing in Coburg, Melbourne. A collection of 8mm home movies including:
Sword family life, including holidays in the 1970s
Fictional student films from Eaglehawk Primary, north of Bendigo
Melbourne scenes inlcuding Tullamarine Airport
School camp
Bendigo Show
Hanging Rock excursion
Moonee Ponds
Indonesia - Denpasar
Fellowship trip to the USA

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Titled Walking to School.
This could possibly be an Eaglehawk Primary School Production.

This narrative film follows the eventful journey of a young school boy as he walks to school along a country road. On the way he is joined by school friends and we see their encounters with a variety of native Australian Wildlife. They see lace monitor tracks and follow them to where the monitor is scaling a tree. They also find a possum and an echidna. The film shows various closeups of the animals and the children’s faces as they squint and shield their eyes from the sun.

The children cross a wooden bridge where they meet an old man carrying a swag and a billy. The man gathers the children around him and reads a story to them called “The Bear”. The film then shows us the story as it is being told. It is a tale of a young girl who is very poor, very dirty and very sad. One day she finds a toy koala which brings her great joy. Excitedly she tries to show her Koala to other school children who are playing games in the school yard. They ridicule her and throw sticks at her. She runs away and falls on the grass where she drifts off to sleep. She dreams that she is rescued by a fairy Godmother who transforms her into a very clean girl in a beautiful dress! During this sequence we see good examples of Super 8 “special effects” as the fairy works her magic on the other children, transforming them into characters in fancy dress. We see these children playing circle games and closeups of their faces. Eventually the poor girl wakes up to find a kind school boy standing over her. He helps her to her feet, takes her hand and leads her to join his other friends. Together the group skip happily all the way to school along a country road.

This film shows good examples of children’s fashion, games and faces. We also see footage of houses and streets of the time.

Selected Highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 Title card ‘Walking to School’
00:00:30:00 Goanna climbing tree
00:02:23:00 Echidna
00:03:45:00 Kids story time reading from ‘The Bear’

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).
results.brief_description:
The William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on Standard 8mm film, featuring travels in the 1960s.

William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sights of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

In this film, Billy travels to Taiping, Malaysia and Tarakan, Borneo and then journeys throughout Australia during 1961.

This film was originally made using standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film has a few scenes from Billy’s travels to Taiping in Malaysia before moving on to Sydney and Melbourne. Billy includes some lovely scenes of being at sea, ships and shipping. The scenes in Sydney include the Harbour, the Bridge and some busy streets. In Melbourne we see the Moomba Parade, trams and vintage cars along St Kilda Road, the Yarra River and the Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southbank.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 on board ship
00:00:33:00 two passengers disembarking in Malaysia
00:00:43:00 views of traditional Malaysian housing
00:00:55:00 people cycling along roads in Taiping, Malaysia
00:01:09:00 women standing with local children in Taiping, all smiling at the camera
00:01:20:00 a woman walking toward embarkation area for a ship
00:02:12:00 great shot of a passenger ship speeding along through the water
00:03:45:00 (possibly) Pulau Pising Lighthouse on Banana Island in the Malacca Straits.
00:04:58:00 a glimpse of some passengers on board ship as they lean over the rail coming into Sydney Harbour.
00:05:43:00 a large liner at berth
00:06:10:00 military ship in Sydney Harbour
00:06:40:00 travelling over the Harbour Bridge by car
00:07:23:00 yachts on the Harbour
00:08:43:00 sign for ‘Wollongong’ followed by an early model Holden (EK)
00:12:13:00 Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southgate, Melbourne, followed by the Yarra River, river boats and Princes Bridge.
00:12:54:00 Circa 1960s (and earlier) cars and trams on St Kilda Road in Melbourne
00:13:13:00 Moomba Parade in Melbourne
00:13:39:00 a decorated ‘A.L.P’ (Australian Labor Party) parade float
00:13:43:00 the ‘Magga Dan Esberg’ ship at a berth.
00:16:50:00 Anzac Day Parade.

group.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film contains scenes of Billy’s travels on the steamship Southern Cross, in 1960 which travelled between Australia and Europe. It is a little difficult to locate exactly where Billy visits but we can definitely see scenes of England, the Netherlands and Greece. The SS Southern Cross was a modern passenger ship built in 1955 to an innovative design which catered specifically for the tourist trade, starting a trend of ‘aft-engined’ ships, leaving more space for passengers and their needs. The Southern Cross was also the first major liner to have no cargo space, other than for ship’s stores and passenger luggage.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of a shoreline and sea
00:01:14:00 a large ship or ferry being loaded at the dock
00:01:48:00 a large and busy tugboat
00:01:50:00 passengers playing tennis on the deck of a ship
00:02:30:00 South Africa Airways airplane on the tarmac
00:03:15:00 a large fountain in a town setting
00:03:49:00 mountain views followed by a picturesque river flowing through hills
00:04:23:00 passengers travelling from a ship, in what appears to be a large lifeboat, to shore
00:04:51:00 views of a large military memorial in a public square setting.
00:04:58:00 dancers in traditional costume give an exhibition of Greek folk dancing to passengers on board a ship.
00:06:19:00 town houses and buildings overlooking houseboats moored on the banks of a canal, with a sign for Grachten (canal)
00:06:58:00 tramcar in a town
00:07:14:00 a large and crowded beach
00:07:36:00 street scenes
00:08:15:00 keen swimmers in a canal or river
00:08:24:00 a glimpse of a windmill
00:08:50:00 boats, ferries and yachts in a bay
00:09:30:00 a passenger ship arrives at a dock
00:10:54:00 scenes of lovely hills and farmlands, thatched cottages and beaches
00:12:15:00 a ‘Punch and Judy’ tent indicates that Billy is in England
00:14:50:00 a plane is filmed overhead
00:15:15:00 a Greek ‘Evezone’ presidential guard dressed in traditional costume
00:16:16:00 a spectacular view of mountain seen at the end of a street, behind shops and buildings, probably in Greece

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film contains scenes of Billy’s travels on the steamship Southern Cross, in 1960 which travelled between Australia and Europe. It is a little difficult to locate exactly where Billy visits but we can definitely see scenes of England, the Netherlands and Greece. The SS Southern Cross was a modern passenger ship built in 1955 to an innovative design which catered specifically for the tourist trade, starting a trend of ‘aft-engined’ ships, leaving more space for passengers and their needs. The Southern Cross was also the first major liner to have no cargo space, other than for ship’s stores and passenger luggage.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of a shoreline and sea
00:01:14:00 a large ship or ferry being loaded at the dock
00:01:48:00 a large and busy tugboat
00:01:50:00 passengers playing tennis on the deck of a ship
00:02:30:00 South Africa Airways airplane on the tarmac
00:03:15:00 a large fountain in a town setting
00:03:49:00 mountain views followed by a picturesque river flowing through hills
00:04:23:00 passengers travelling from a ship, in what appears to be a large lifeboat, to shore
00:04:51:00 views of a large military memorial in a public square setting.
00:04:58:00 dancers in traditional costume give an exhibition of Greek folk dancing to passengers on board a ship.
00:06:19:00 town houses and buildings overlooking houseboats moored on the banks of a canal, with a sign for Grachten (canal)
00:06:58:00 tramcar in a town
00:07:14:00 a large and crowded beach
00:07:36:00 street scenes
00:08:15:00 keen swimmers in a canal or river
00:08:24:00 a glimpse of a windmill
00:08:50:00 boats, ferries and yachts in a bay
00:09:30:00 a passenger ship arrives at a dock
00:10:54:00 scenes of lovely hills and farmlands, thatched cottages and beaches
00:12:15:00 a ‘Punch and Judy’ tent indicates that Billy is in England
00:14:50:00 a plane is filmed overhead
00:15:15:00 a Greek ‘Evezone’ presidential guard dressed in traditional costume
00:16:16:00 a spectacular view of mountain seen at the end of a street, behind shops and buildings, probably in Greece

group.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).
